subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Fundamentals of Operations Management
headline: Discover the relationship between operations, productivity, and competitiveness with this operations management course.
description: This free online operations management course in the fundamentals of operations management will teach you about the central principles, practices, and standards of effective operations management. By the end of the course, you will understand the crucial operations management practices of planning, organizing, coordinating, and controlling of all the resources needed to produce a company's goods and services so they are fit for their market.
courseDescription:
This free online operations management and strategy course begins by giving an overview of operations management in both manufacturing and service organisations. You will learn about the different strategies which you can apply to your company and will study capacity planning, facilities location planning, aggregate planning, and scheduling. This can help you ensure that your company's products or services are always available and reach your customers promptly. The course will then explain the relationship between operations, productivity, and competitiveness.

You will then study the nine key characteristics of an operations manager and the critical decisions managers must make when managing operations in an organisation. You will learn how they help in the development of plans or tactics that could give their company a competitive edge over its competitors. The course will also cover inventory management techniques that can help you control and oversee your company's inventory and the amount of product for sale.

Every successful operations manager needs to be able to handle the day-to-day running of their business smoothly. This free operations management strategy course will familiarize you with production administration, manufacturing, and the rendering of services in order to make you much more capable of becoming that successful manager. Check out the course today, and give your professional advancement a boost in just a few short hours.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Having completed this module you will be able to
    • Define operations management
    • Discuss the relationship between operations, productivity and competitiveness
    • Identify the characteristics of an operations manager
    • List the nine key strategy areas 
    • Explain the role of quality management in operations
    • Explain inventory management techniques

  • Introduction

  • Every organisation attempts to be successful in the market place by obtaining an acceptable market share through competitive strategies. In order to obtain and then to hold a competitive edge or advantage over competitors, organisations must produce goods or services that are competitive in their respective markets.

  • Inventory management

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • An effective operations management system will not only involve planning the operations but also controlling the costs associated with these operations. These costs may be classified as either direct or indirect costs. Direct costs are those costs directly related to output and in direct proportion to that output level e.g. supplies and employee costs. Indirect costs are those costs that are incurred irrespective of output levels e.g. rent and other related occupancy costs. Management of organisations must pay particular attention to the costs associated with the availability, purchase price and quality of its resources.

  • Summary of key learning points for Corporate Management

  • Operations Management (OM) involves the designing, planning, organising, leading and controlling functions involved in the production of a good or the provision of a service.

    The differences between manufacturing and service organisations  include the facts that a the customer of a service organisation is directly involved in the production process of the service being purchased whereas the end products of a manufacturing organisation may be stored or held as inventory.

    Increases in productivity are dependent upon both people and operations variables and are a significant contributor to improved business competitiveness.

    The development of efficient and effective operating systems organisations use both Strategic Planning Decisions and  Tactical Planning Decisions
